Award.AwardTitle: NSF/FDA Scholar In Residence: 3D Cell Adhesion Assay for Cellularized Scaffold Characterization and Enhancement

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT
PI: Fisher, John
Proposal Number: 1641087

3D Printing (3DP) is increasing tissue engineering (TE) applications through rapid manufacture of custom scaffolds wherein precision architectures can mimic native tissue. TE applications involving multipotent stem cells, 3DP constructs, and extracellular matrix (ECM) materials have become increasingly prevalent. In order to translate these technologies as therapeutics it is necessary to understand cell behavior within the 3D environment. An ongoing FDA-University of Maryland (UMD) collaboration has led to the development and characterization of a cell adhesion centrifugation (CAC) assay to enhance isolation and differentiation of mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) from bone marrow. This proposal will enhance the utility of the established assay for use with 3D constructs. It will also provide useful insight into cell-scaffold interaction in three dimensions that will inform standardization criteria. The work will partner researchers, faculty and students at the University of Maryland and the FDA.

The development of the CAC assay to accommodate 3D scaffold designs has the potential to minimize the translational distance for TE therapies by providing a mechanism to characterize and purify cells within 3D constructs. The cellular capture device will stabilize 3D scaffolds and allow characterization of non-adherent cells based on integrin-ligand binding. The key aims are: 1) investigate MSC behavior and purification from bone marrow seeded onto 3D constructs through adaptation of the CAC assay wherein the impact of centrifugation force, incubation time, and 3D construct architecture will be evaluated: 2) investigate the interaction of MSCs with 3D ECM-polymer scaffolds through examination of multi-lineage differentiation potential enabled by ECM additives to 3DP scaffold adhesion and differentiation capacity: and 3)investigate the capture and characterization of non-adhered cells collected using the CAC assays. This will allow the FDA to further develop the CAC assay and to evaluate its utility as a method to characterize the cellular component 3D construct based therapies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In anticipation of budding translational technologies utilizing 3DP and multipotent stem cells, it is pertinent that the FDA is proficient in the use of 3DP and cell behavior within 3DP constructs. Our previously awarded NSF-FDA SIR research generated a practical assay for enhancing isolation purity and the differentiation capacity of MSCs. We also demonstrated the utility of cell adhesion for characterizing differentiation capacity and as a response to surface modification. Further development of the CAC assay to accommodate 3D scaffold designs has the potential to minimize the translational distance for TE therapies by providing a mechanism to characterize and purify cells within 3D constructs.

Additive manufacturing technologies have gained popularity for the production of microporous scaffolds for bioengineering purposes. Stereolithography-based 3D printing, such as continuous digital light processing (cDLP), can produce high resolution constructs for the development of bone regeneration devices. The large number of parameters involved in cDLP can be used to produce constructs with a wide variety of mechanical and biochemical properties. The orientation of the part during the printing process can generally affect the mechanical properties and accuracy of the constructs, and can influence other factors relevant to the print production including supporting structures, print time, layering, shrinkage, or surface roughness. However, this effect has not been studied systematically for cDLP methods. Here, we investigated the effects of print orientation on the print accuracy of microstructural features using microCT imaging and mechanical properties of cDLP microporous scaffolds in multiple loading modes. MicroCT imaging revealed that microstructural features in horizontally printed structures exhibited greater agreement to the design dimension than vertically printed constructs. This effect is a combination of the print resin viscosity and the orientation of pores and spacing within the structure which alters how uncrosslinked resin flows within the construct during printing. Uniaxial compression showed significant effects of print orientation on the compressive modulus for all porous structures independent of the resin material, with vertically printed scaffolds having increased mechanical resistance. In contrast, the compression-torsion biaxial assessment of cDLP constructs was consistent between print orientations. We concluded that while cDLP technologies have the potential to produce mechanically isotropic solid constructs because of bond homogeneity, the effect of print orientation on microstructural feature sizes can result in structurally anisotropic porous constructs.


Last Modified: 05/29/2019
Modified by: John P Fisher
